pageProps.body:
Equidimensional Equations

We take a brief, contractually-obligated segue from our studies in inhomogeneous equations to arrive at equidimensional DEs.

Definition. (Equidimensional equations). Also known as the Euler equation, because of course it is, we define an equidimensional equation to be of the form

L[y]=x2y′′+αxy′+βy=g(x)L[y] = x^2y'' + \alpha xy' + \beta y = g(x)L[y]=x2y′′+αxy′+βy=g(x)

It is named so because every term (x2y′′,xy′,yx^2y'', xy', yx2y′′,xy′,y) is of the same dimension; if yyy was in meters and xxx in seconds, then y′y'y′ would be the rate of change of yyy (m/s), y′′y''y′′ would be in m/s2^22, and so every term in the DE have the same dimensions.

The method behind solving such equations is largely similar to constant-coefficient equations: solving by eigenfunctions.

Method. (Solving equidimensional equations by eigenfunctions).

Notice that y=xky=x^ky=xk for any kkk is an eigenfunction of the equation: e.g. x2y′′=x2(k)(k−1)xk−2=k(k−1)yx^2y'' = x^2(k)(k-1)x^{k-2} = k(k-1)yx2y′′=x2(k)(k−1)xk−2=k(k−1)y, a constant multiple of yyy. Simply set y=xky = x^ky=xk to obtain a characteristic equation in kkk:

k(k−1)+αk+β=0k(k-1) + \alpha k + \beta = 0k(k−1)+αk+β=0

If there are two real solutions for kkk - k1k_1k1​ and k2k_2k2​ - then (as the Wronskian would attest) xk1x^{k_1}xk1​ and xk2x^{k_2}xk2​ are the two fundamental solutions. The same goes for two distinct complex roots a+bia+bia+bi and a−bia-bia−bi:

y=Axa+bi+Bxa−bi=Aeln⁡xa+bi+Beln⁡xa−bi=Ae(a+bi)ln⁡x+Be(a−bi)ln⁡x=Aealn⁡xeb(ln⁡x)i+Bealn⁡xe−b(ln⁡x)i=Axa(cos⁡(bln⁡x)+isin⁡(bln⁡x))+Bxa(cos⁡(bln⁡x)−isin⁡(bln⁡x))\begin{aligned} y &= Ax^{a+bi} + Bx^{a-bi} \\ &= Ae^{\ln x^{a+bi}} + Be^{\ln x^{a-bi}} \\ &= Ae^{(a+bi)\ln x} + Be^{(a-bi)\ln x} \\ &= Ae^{a\ln x}e^{b(\ln x)i} + Be^{a\ln x}e^{-b(\ln x)i} \\ &= Ax^a(\cos (b\ln x) + i\sin (b\ln x)) + Bx^a(\cos (b\ln x) - i\sin (b\ln x)) \end{aligned}y​=Axa+bi+Bxa−bi=Aelnxa+bi+Belnxa−bi=Ae(a+bi)lnx+Be(a−bi)lnx=Aealnxeb(lnx)i+Bealnxe−b(lnx)i=Axa(cos(blnx)+isin(blnx))+Bxa(cos(blnx)−isin(blnx))​

by Euler's formula. This has real part

Axacos⁡(bln⁡x)+Bxasin⁡(bln⁡x)Ax^a\cos (b\ln x) + Bx^a\sin (b \ln x)Axacos(blnx)+Bxasin(blnx)

In order to deal with the repeated root (degeneracy) case, we need a different method as we can no longer multiply the first solution by xxx. Thus, we attempt a substitution:

Method. (Substitution for repeated-root equidimensional equations).

We don't quite know how to deal with equidimensional equations (with xkx^kxk as the solutions) yet, but we do know how to deal with constant-coefficient equations (with ekxe^{kx}ekx as solutions). Let's try the substitution z=ln⁡x,dzdx=1xz=\ln x, \frac{dz}{dx} = \frac{1}{x}z=lnx,dxdz​=x1​. Then:

z=ln⁡x  ⟺  x=ezy(x)=y(ez)dydz=y′(ez)ez=xy′d2ydz2=ezy′(ez)+e2zy′′(ez)=xy′+x2y′′\begin{aligned} z = \ln x &\iff x = e^z \\ y(x) &= y(e^z) \\ \frac{dy}{dz} &= y'(e^z) e^z = xy' \\ \frac{d^2y}{dz^2} &= e^z y'(e^z) + e^{2z}y''(e^z) = xy' + x^2y'' \end{aligned}z=lnxy(x)dzdy​dz2d2y​​⟺x=ez=y(ez)=y′(ez)ez=xy′=ezy′(ez)+e2zy′′(ez)=xy′+x2y′′​

and thus

x2y′′+αxy′+βy=g(x)  ⟺  (d2ydz2−dydz)+αdydz+βy=g(ez)=d2ydz2+(α−1)dydz+βy\begin{aligned} x^2 y'' + \alpha x y' + \beta y = g(x) &\iff (\frac{d^2 y}{dz^2} - \frac{dy}{dz}) + \alpha \frac{dy}{dz} + \beta y = g(e^z) \\ &= \frac{d^2 y}{dz^2} + (\alpha - 1)\frac{dy}{dz} + \beta y \end{aligned}x2y′′+αxy′+βy=g(x)​⟺(dz2d2y​−dzdy​)+αdzdy​+βy=g(ez)=dz2d2y​+(α−1)dzdy​+βy​

which is a standard constant-coefficient DE, with characteristic equation λ2+(α−1)λ+β=0\lambda^2 + (\alpha-1)\lambda + \beta=0λ2+(α−1)λ+β=0. If there is a repeated root λ\lambdaλ, then:

y=(Az+B)eλz=(Aln⁡x+B)eλln⁡x=(Aln⁡x+B)xλy = (Az+B)e^{\lambda z} = (A\ln x + B)e^{\lambda \ln x} = (A\ln x + B)x^{\lambda}y=(Az+B)eλz=(Alnx+B)eλlnx=(Alnx+B)xλ

which is the desired result for the repeated root case. It is worth noting that, analogously to how we multiply by xxx when a guess for a particular integral fails, we multiply by ln⁡x\ln xlnx in the case of an equidimensional equation.
